quot.text: the conclusion of arguably the greatest 14-year run in rock history

doc.text:
Bowie felt he had to continue to pander to the new mass audience he acquired with the album
, which led to him releasing two further solo albums in 1984 and 1987 which
, despite their relative commercial success
, did not sell as well as
, were poorly received by critics at the time and subsequently dismissed by Bowie himself as his
Bowie would help form the hard rock and
-predecessor band
in 1989 in an effort to rejuvenate himself artistically.

doc.text: David Bowie had planned to use producer

on the album
, as the two had worked together on Bowie's previous four studio albums. However
, he chose Nile Rodgers for the project
, a move that came as a surprise to Visconti
, who had set time aside to work on

. Visconti called
[Bowie's personal assistant
] Coco and she said
:

quot.text:
Well
, you might as well know
– he's been in the studio for the past two weeks with someone else. It's working out well and we won't be needing you. He's very sorry.

doc.text:
The move damaged the two men's relationship and Visconti did not work with Bowie again for nearly 20 years
(until 2002's
Rodgers later recalled that Bowie approached him to produce his album so that Bowie could have hit singles.
Rodgers reported that Bowie came into his apartment one day and showed him a photograph of

in a red suit getting into a bright red Cadillac
, saying

quot.text:
Nile
, darling
, that's what I want my album to sound like.

doc.text:
, Bowie's previous album
, was his last with the
label. He later signed with
for a reported $17.5 million and was working with Rodgers to release a
album that was described as

Bowie spent three days making demos for the album in New York before cutting the album
, a rarity for Bowie who
, for the previous few albums
, usually showed up with little more than

quot.text: a few ideas.

Despite this
, the album

quot.text:
was recorded

met Bowie at the 1982

in Switzerland. After Vaughan's performance

quot.text:
[he
] completely floored me. I probably hadn't been so gung-ho about a guitar player since seeing
with his band the Tridents.

Of Bowie
, Vaughan said
, to

doc.text:
tell you the truth
, I was not very familiar with David's music when he asked me to play on the sessions. ... David and I talked for hours and hours about

and its roots
– I was amazed at how interested he was. At Montreux
, he said something about being in touch and then tracked me down in California
, months and months later.

quot.text:
In a contemporary interview
, Vaughan described the recording sessions for the album
:

doc.text:
Unusually
, Bowie played no instruments on the album.

quot.text: I don't play a damned thing. This was a singer's album.

from this album:

Bowie later described the title track the same way

from the way that Nile arranged it.

Bowie played an early demo of the song for Nile Rodgers on a 12-string guitar with only 6 strings strung
, and said to Nile
,

quot.text:
Nile darling
, I think I have a song which feels like it's a hit.

doc.text:
Nile then took the chords
(which he said
) and helped craft them into the version used in the final production of the song.
Long-time collaborator

, who had worked with Bowie since the mid-1970s and would continue to work with Bowie into the mid-1990s
, has claimed was offered an
fee to play on the album and refused to do so.

He also said
(when working on Bowie's follow-up album
,
) that he did not play on

because Bowie only gave him two weeks' notice and he was already booked with other work
;

however
, Alomar did play on the accompanying

cell.text: David Bowie's biggest fans reveal all

attr.text:
David Bowie is real easy to work with. He knows what he's doing in the studio and he doesn't mess around. He comes right in and goes to work. Most of the time
, David did the vocals and then I played my parts. A lot of the time
, he just wanted me to cut loose. He'd give his opinion on the stuff he liked and the stuff that needed work. Almost everything was cut in one or two takes. I think there was only one thing that needed three takes.

cell.text: David Bowie Opens Up – A Little

attr.text:
I thought it was a great song
, and the beat wasn't quite right. It didn't roll the way it should have
, the syncopation was wrong. It had an ungainly gait
; it should have flowed. ... Nile
[Rodgers
] did his own thing to it
, but it wasn't quite what I'd had in mind when I wrote the thing.

The album was seen as a commercial and critical success by professional critics
, though opinions varied on the artistic content
; while one reviewer called it

pleaded shamelessly for the love of the mass market

Writing for

in 2014
, Jeremy Allen stated that

quot.text:
spent time in the wilderness
, rejected by many because of its 80s production values

doc.text: , but he added that

quot.text: a reappraisal was all but inevitable and has coincided with a renaissance in Rodgers' career and an outpouring of love for the unprecedentedly successful producer/guitarist.

doc.text:
In 1989
, the album was ranked number 83 on
magazine's list of the

quot.text: 100 Best Albums of the Eighties

doc.text: Although Bowie had charged producer

with making hits for him
,

quot.text:
at the time
,

was not mainstream. It was virtually a new kind of hybrid
, using blues-rock guitar against a dance format. There wasn't anything else that really quite sounded like that at the time. So it only seems commercial in hindsight because it sold so many
[copies
]. It was great in its way
, but it put me in a real corner in that it fucked with my integrity.

doc.text:
Bowie recalled
,

quot.text:
[It
] was a good record
, but it was only meant as a one-off project. I had every intention of continuing to do some unusual material after that. But the success of that record really forced me
, in a way
, to continue the beast. It was my own doing
, of course
, but I felt
, after a few years
, that I had gotten stuck.

doc.text: Bowie later said that the success of the album caused him to hit a creative low point in his career which lasted the next few years.

quot.text:
I remember looking out over these waves of people
[who were coming to hear this record played live
] and thinking
, 'I wonder how many

albums these people have in their record collections?' I suddenly felt very apart from my audience. And it was depressing
, because I didn't know what they wanted.

doc.text: After his follow-up albums
Bowie formed the grunge-precursor band
in an effort to regain his artistic vision.

ref.text: Mary Campbell for the Associated Press, 6 August 1993

doc.text: All songs written by

re-released the album on CD with

In 1998
, there was a reissue in the UK which was similar to the 1995 re-release but did not include the bonus track.

The Canadian version of the 1999 EMI release includes a data track
, so that when the CD is loaded on a

PC
, the user is presented with a promotion of internet access services and other premium content from the davidbowie.com website. This marks one of the earliest attempts by a mainstream artist to combine internet and normal promotion and distribution methods.
There was a further reissue in 2003 when EMI released the album as a hybrid stereo
CD.
The album was re-mastered in 2018 and released in the box set
Credits are adapted from the album's liner notes.
